International had a big vese of flowers.
We had dinner alone in Ciros
anid peintings of Diego Rivers - some of which would not have net with
Mother's approval.
The next day we went for a sightseeing trip with Mrs. Rihi to the
National Pewn Shop--lergest in the world.
Unlike the meller emporiuns
presided over by the elen of Cohen in the U.S., this one did not have
the three bells outside.
Visited the Cathedrel--much the same ar all
others--ditto the Palace of the Emperor Maximilian.
However, we loved
the ride through the residential area with its colorful houses, mostly
of the Spenish-colonial type, surrounded by gardens with flowers of
every variety on lawns, walls, window bozes, and even roofs.
afternoon, E.C.B. continued sightseeing while I talked shop.
Cocktails
and dinner at the Bankers Club.
This norning we got out to the airport
in plenty of time, only to leara that our plane ves delayed - an eleven
o'clock departure instead of nine.
He had breskfeet and presently Ceorge
Rihl showed up to see us off, but instead drove us out to Guedeloupa to
see the Cathedral there.
It la relly beautiful. The priests were con-
ducting sore kind of service and the big church was chook full of deeply
religious Mexicans, mostly of the peon type.
Back at the airport, we
got away on a DC-3 operated by Cia Mexicans, and now as I write, were
flying over the bay of Campeche toward Merida.
Arriving Merida about 4130 p.m., we were met by the PAA menager and
a representative of the Barbschano tourist bureau, who suggested that we
leave right away for Chichen Itzs, some one hundred miles east of keride
in the center of the province of Tucatan.
We drove into Merida from the
changed curs, and with our English-speaking guide-chauffeur started
our trip about 5:00 p.m.
sunset behind us and high-piled white
clouds ahead provided daylight for about half the
journey over & fine road.
He drove through flelds of "green god"
as they cell the sisal plantations,
then stretches of
jungle, fields of corn and little villages of thetched
huts--clean as a mistle, as were the people, too.
We stopped at a little
barrio for a coca cola,
where the "manager"
presented Debby
with a beeutiful
white flower which looked like an orchid and
smelled like a gardenia - then
continued in the dark.
Cattle gresing along the road were such a hazard that
our driver - thank
goodness - could not speed even if he had
wanted to do so.
The lest ten miles of road was very
rough going but entirely sefe and
passable.
We arrived at the ruins about
8:00 p.m.,
and our guide turned off
his headlights for a few moments
that we could
see the pyramid and the
temple of warriors by moonlight - a never-to-be-forgotten impression.
lodge ie unique.
A central dining room
with spacious porch is set in a grove
of large trees and interspersed
with orange, line, lenon and
grapefruit trees,
plus flowering shrubs,
bougainvilla, and other flowering vines.
walk led down to an
oval-shaped stucco thatch-roofed cottege
surrounded by &
broad porch under the extensive overhang of the roof.
Inside a partition
divided the oval room into a bedroom and
Most attractive and appropriate.
